Though not in name a widdow.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: Pray a word Tee,
Shall I in earneſt never be your bedfellow?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Never, ô never; and tis for your good too.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: Prove that.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas too many yeares are numbred
In my account to entertaine the benefit
Which youth in thee Ceſario and ability
Might hope for and require, it were Injuſtice
To rob a gentleman deſerving memory
Of Iſſue to preſerve it.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: No more herein,
You are an excellent patterne of true piety,
Let me now turne your advocate. Pray looke into
The order of the Duke, Jnjoynd, admit
J ſatisfie the ſentence without mariage
with you, how then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ceſario.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: If I know
How to acquit your feares, yet keepe th'injunction
In every clauſe whole and entire, your charity
Will call me ſtill your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Still my ſon.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: Right Madam, now you have it, ſtill your ſon.
The Genius of your bleſſings hath inſtructed
Your tongue oraculouſly, wee wil forget
How once I and Clariſſa enterchangd
The tyes of brother and of ſiſter, henceforth
New ſtile us man and wife.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: By what authority

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: Heavens great appointment, yet in all my dotage
On thy perfections, when I thought Clariſſa
Wee had beene pledges of one wombe, no looſe
No wanton heat of youth, deſir'd to claime
Priority in thy affections, other
Then nature might commend. Chaſtly I tendred
Thy farewell as a brother ought; but ſince
Our bloods are ſtrangers, let our hearts contract
A long life-laſting unity, for this way
The ſentence is to be obſervd or no way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then no way.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: I expected other anſwer Madam from you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, every age ſhall curſe me,
The monſter, and the prodigie of nature,
Horrors beyond extremity,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Pray mother confine the violence of greife

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: Yes mother, pray do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus ſome catch at a matrons honor
By flying luſt to plot Inceſtuous witchcrafts,
More terrible then whoredomes; cruell mercy
When to preſerve the body from a death
The ſoule is ſtrangled.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: This is more then paſſion.
It comes neere to diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am quieted.
Ceſario, thou maieſt tell the Duke ſecurely
Albertos titles, honors and revenues,
The Duke may give away, Injoy them thou.
Clariſſas birthright, Marianas dower
Thou ſhalt be Lord of; turne us to the world
Vnpittyed and unfreinded, yet my bed
Thou never ſleep'ſt in; as for her; ſhe heares me,
If ſhe as much as in a thoughts conſent;
That thou may'ſt call her wife, a Mothers curſe
Shall never leave her.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: As a brother once
I lov'd you, as a noble freind yet honor ye,
But for a husband ſir, I dare not owne you,
My faith is given already.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: To a Villaine, Ile cut his throat.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why this is more then paſſion?
It comes neere a diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Call to minde Sir.
How much you have abated of that goodneſſe
Which once raign'd in ye, they appear'd ſo lovely
That ſuch as freindſhip led to obſervation
Courted the great example.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: Left and flatterd into abroad deriſion

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why dee thinke ſo?
My Lord Baptiſta, is your ſonne growne cold
In haſting on the marriage, which his vowes
Have ſeald to my wrongd daughter?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Wee come Lady, to conſummate the contract.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: With Mentivole? is he the man?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Clariſſas, troth and mine,
Ceſario are recorded in a character
So plaine and certaine, that except the hand
Of heaven, which writ it firſt, would blot it out againe,
No human power can raze it.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: But ſay you ſo too? young Lady,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I ſhould els betray
My heart to falſhood, and my tongue to perjury.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: Madam, you know the ſentence.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: From the Duke,
I have particular comforts which require
A private eare.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I ſhall approve it gladly,
Wee are reſolvd Ceſario.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Be not inſolent upon a Princes favour.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Looſe no glory,
Your younger yeares have purchaſt.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: And deſervd too y'have many worthy freinds.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.p: Preſerve and uſe them. Exeunt: Manet Ceſar.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: Good, very good, why heres a complement
Of mirth in deſperation, I could curſe
My fate. ô with what ſpeed men tumble downe
From hopes that ſoare to high. Biancha now
May ſcorne me juſtly too, Clariſſa married,
Albertos widdow reſolute, Biancha
Refuſd, and I forſaken, let me ſtudy,
I can but dye a Batchelor thats the worſt on't. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Hoſt, Taylor, Muliter, Dancer, Pedant, Coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen,
This is the day that our great artiſt hath
Promiſt to give all your ſeverall ſuites ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Dancer.
sp.l: Is he ſtirring?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: He hath beene at his booke theſe two houres.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: Hees a rare Phyſitian.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why Ile tell you,
Were Paracelſus the German now
Living, heed take up his ſingle rapier againſt his
Terrible long ſword, he makes it a matter of nothing
To cure the goute, ſore eyes he takes out as familiarly,
Waſhes them, and puts them in againe,
As you'd blanch almonds.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: They ſay he can make gold.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: I, I, he learnt it of Kelly in Germany.
Theres not a Chimiſt
In chriſtendome can goe beyond him for multiplying.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: Take heed then,
He get not up your daughters belly my Hoſt.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: You are a merry Gentleman
And the man of art will love you the better.

sp.speaker: Dancer.
sp.l: Does he love mirth and crotchets?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: O hees the moſt courteous Phyſitian,
You may drink or drab in's company freely,
The better he knowes how your diſeaſe growes,
The better he knowes how to cure it.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: But I wonder my Hoſt
He has no more reſort of Ladyes to him.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: O divers of them have great beleife in conjurers
Lechery is a great helpe to the quality.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Hee's ſcarce knowne to be in towne yet,
Ere long we ſhall have em come
hurring hither in Fetherbeds.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: How? bedridden.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: No ſir, in fetherbeds that move upon 4 wheeles in Spaniſh caroches.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Pray acquaint him we give attendance.

sp.speaker: Host,
sp.l: I ſhall gentlemen. I would faine be rid
Of theſe raſcalls, but that they raiſe profit
To my wine-ſeller;
When I have made uſe of them ſufficiently,
I will intreat the conjurer to tye crackers to their tailes,
And ſend them packing.

div.stage: Enter Foroboſco as in his Study. (A paper)

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Come hither mine Hoſt looke here.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A challenge from my man.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: For breakings pate?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: He writes here if I meet him not
Ith Feild within this halfe houre,
I ſhall heare more from him.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: O ſir, minde your profit,
Nere thinke of the raſcall, here are the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Morrow my worthy clients,
What are you all prepard of your queſtions?
That I may give my reſolution upon them,

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We are ſir.

sp.speaker: Pedant,
sp.l: And have brought our mony.

sp.speaker: Foro
sp.l: Each then in order,
And differ not for precedency.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I am buying of an office ſir,
And to that purpoſe I would faine learne
to diſſemble cunningly.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Doe you come to me for that? you ſhould rather
Have gone to a cunning woman.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: I ſir but their Inſtructions are but like women,
Pretty well but not to the depth, as I'do have it,
You are a conjurer, the devils maſter,
And I would learn it from you ſo exactly,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That the divill himſelfe
Might not go beyond you,

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: You are ith right ſir.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: And ſo your mony for your purchaſe
Might come in againe within a 12 month.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: I would be a Graduate ſir, no freſhman.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Heres my hand ſir,
I will make you diſſemble ſo methodically,
As if the divell ſhould be ſent from the great Turke,
In the ſhape of an Embaſſador
To ſet all the chriſtian princes at variance.

sp.speaker: Danc.
sp.l: I cannot with any modeſty deſire any more,
Theres your mony ſir,

sp.speaker: Foco.
sp.l: For the art of diſſembling.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: My ſuite ſir will be newes to you when I tell it,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Pray on.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: I would ſet up a preſſe here in Italy,
To write all the Caranta for Chriſtendome.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Thats newes indeed,
And how would you imploy me in't?

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: Marry ſir, from you
I would gaine my intelligence.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: I conceave you, you would have me furniſh you
With a ſpirit to informe you.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: But as quiet a Divell as the woman,
The firſt day and a halfe after ſhe's married,
I can by no meanes indure a terrible one.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: No, no, Ile qualifie him,
He ſhall not fright you,
It ſhall be the ghoſt of ſome lying Stationer,
sp.p: A Spirit ſhall looke as if butter would not melt in his mouth, A new Mercurius Gallobelgicus.

sp.speaker: Coxc.
sp.l: O there was a captaine was rare at it,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Nere thinke of him,
Though that captaine writ a full hand gallop,
And waſted indeed more harmeleſſe paper then
Ever did laxative Phyſick,
Yet wil I make you to out-ſcribble him,
And ſet downe what you pleaſe,
The world ſhall better beleeve you.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.l: Worthy ſir I thanke you, there's mony.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A new office
For writing pragmaticall Curranto's

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: I am a ſchoole-maſter ſir,
And would faine conferre with you
About erecting 4 new ſects of religion at Amſterdam.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: What the Divell ſhould
New ſects of religion doe there?

sp.speaker: Pedaot.
sp.l: I aſſure you I would get
A great deale of mony by it.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: And what are the 4 new ſects
Of religion you would plant there?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Why thats it I come about ſir,
Tis a Divel of your raiſing muſt invent 'em,
I confeſſe I am too weake to compaſſe it.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: So ſir, then you make it a matter of no difficulty
To have them tolerated.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.l: Trouble not your ſelfe for that,
Let but your Divel ſet them a foot once,
I have Weavers, and Ginger-bread makers,
And mighty Aquavitae-men, ſhall ſet them a going.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: This is ſomewhat difficult,
And will aske ſome conference with the divell.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Take your owne leaſure ſir,
I have another buſines too, becauſe I meane
To leave Jtaly, and bury my ſelfe in thoſe neather parts
Of the low countries.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Whats that ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Marry I would faine make 9 dayes to the weeke, for the more ample benefit of the captaine.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: You have a ſhrewd pate ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: But how this might be compaſd?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Compaſd eaſily; tis but making
A new Almanacke, and dividing the compaſſe
Of the yeare into larger penny-worths,
As a Chandler with his compaſſe makes
A Geometrick proportion of the Holland cheeſe
He retailes by ſtivers.
But for getting of it licenc'd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Trouble not your ſelfe with that ſir,
Theres your mony,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: For foure new ſects of religions,
And 9 dayes to the weeke.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: To be brought in at generall pay-dayes,
Write I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: At generall pay-dayes.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: I am by profeſſion a taylor,
You have heard of me.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Yes ſir, and will not ſteale from you
The leaſt part of that commendation I have heard utterd.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.l: I take meaſure of your worth ſir,
And becauſe I will not afflict you with any large bill
Of circumſtances, I will ſnip off particulars.
I would faine invent ſome ſtrange
And exquiſite new faſhions.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Are you not travel'd ſir.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Yes ſir, but have obſerv'd all we can ſee
Or invent are but old ones with new names to'em,
Now I would ſome way or other grow more curious.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Let me ſee to deviſe new faſhions.
Were you never in the Moone?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: In the Moone taverne! yes ſir: often.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: No, I do meane in the new world,
In the world thats in the Moone yonder.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: How? a new world ith moone?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Yes I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And peopled?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: O moſt fantaſtically peopled.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Nay certaine then ther's worke for taylors?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That there is I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Yet I have talked with a Scotch taylor
That never diſcover'd ſo much to me,
Though he has travail'd far, and was a pedlar in Poland.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: That was out of his way,
This lies beyond China,
You would ſtudy new faſhions you ſay?
Take my councell, make a voyage,
And diſcover that new world.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Shall I be a moon-man?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: I am of opinion, the people of that world
(Jf they be like the nature of that climate they live in)
Do vary the faſhion of their cloathes oftner then any
Quick-ſilver'd nation in Europe.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Not unlikely, but what ſhould that be we call
The man in the moone then?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Why tis nothing but an Engliſhman
That ſtands there ſtarke naked,
With a paire of ſheires in one hand,
And a great bundle of broad cloath in the other
(Which reſembles the buſh of thornes)
Cutting out of new faſhions.

sp.speaker: Taylor
sp.l: I have heard ſomewhat like this,
But how ſhall I get thither?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Ile make a new compaſſe ſhall direct you.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Certaine?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Count me elſe for no man of direction.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Theres 20 duckats in hand, at my returne
Ile give you a 100.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A new voyage to diſcover new faſhions.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.l: I have been a travailer too ſir,
That have ſhewed ſtrange beaſts in Chriſtendome,
And got mony by them, but I finde the trade to decay.
Your Camelion, or Eaſt-Indian hedg-hog
Gets very little mony, and your Elephant devoures
So much bread, brings in ſo little profit,
His keeper were better every morning
Cram 15 Taylors with white manchet,
I would have ſome new ſpectacle,
And one that might be more attractive.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Let me ſee, were you ever in Spaine?

sp.speaker: Mule.
sp.p: Not yet Sir.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I would have you go to Madrill, and againſt ſome great feſtivall, when the court lies there, provide a great and ſpacious Engilſh Oxe, and rode him whole, with a pudding in's belly; that would be the eight won|der of the world in thoſe parts I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mule.
sp.p: A rare project without queſtion.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Goe beyond all their garlike olla Podrithoes, though you ſod one in Garquentuas cauldron, bring in more mony, then all the monſters of Affrick.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Good Sir do your beſt for him; he's of my ac|quaintance, and one if ye knew him—

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: He was once a man of infinite letters.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: A Scholler?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: No ſir, a packet carrier, which is alwaies a man of many letters, yon know: then he was Mule-driver, now hee's a gentleman, and feedes monſters.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: A moſt ungratefull calling.

sp.speaker: Mule.
sp.p: Ther's mony for your direction; the price of the Oxe Sir.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: A hundred French crownes, for it muſt be a Lin|colne ſhire Oxe, and a prime one:
For a rare and monſtrous ſpectacle, to be ſeen at Madrill.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſ.
sp.p: Pray forbeare ſir, we ſhall have a new quarrell.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: You durſt not meet me ith' field, I am therefore come to ſpoyle your market.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Whats the newes with you ſir.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you that come hither to be moſt abominably cheated, liſten, and be as wiſe as your plan|net will ſuffer you, keep your mony, be not guld, be not laught at.

sp.speaker: Pedant.
sp.p: What meanes this? would I had my mony a|gaine in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: The fellow is full of malice, do not mind him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: This profeſt cheating rogue was my maſter, and I confeſſe my ſelfe a more preternotorious rogue then himſelfe, in ſo long keeping his villainous counſell.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Come, come, I will not heare you.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: No couzner, thou wouldeſt not heare me, I do but dare thee to ſuffer me to ſpeake, and then thou and all thy divells ſpit fire, and ſpoute Aqua fortis.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Speake on, I freely permit thee.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Why then know all you ſimple animals, you whoſe purſes are ready to caſt the calfe, if they have not caſt it already, if you give any credit this jugling raſcal, you are worſe then ſimple widgins, and will be drawne into the net by this decoy ducke, this tame cheater.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, pray marke him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: He does profeſſe Phyſicke, and counjuring; for his Phyſicke; he has but two medicins for all manner of diſeaſes; when he was i'th low countryes, he us'd no|thing but butterd beere, colourd with Allegant, for all kind of maladies, and that he called his catholick med|cine; ſure the ducth ſmelt out it was butterd beere, elſe they would never have endur'd it for the names ſake: then does he miniſter a grated dogs turd inſtead of Rubarbe, many times of Vnicornes horne, which working ſtrong|ly with the conceit of the Patient, would make them be|ſcummer to the height of a mighty purgation.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: The rogue has ſtudied this invective.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Now for his conjuring, the witches of Lapland are the divells chaire-women to him, for they will ſell a man a winde to ſome purpoſe; he ſells winde, and tells you fortye lyes over and over.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſſ.
sp.p: I thought what we ſhould find of him.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Hold your prating, be not you an hereticke.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Conjure! Ile tell you, all the divells names he calls upon, are but fuſtian names, gatherd out of welch heraldry; in breife, he is a rogue of ſix reprieves, foure pardones of courſe, thrice pilloried, twince ſung Lacry|mae to the Virginalls of a carts taile, h'as five times been in the Gallies, and will never truly run himſelfe out of breath, till he comes to the gallowes.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: You have heard worthy gentlemen, what this lying detracting raſcall has vomited.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Yes certaine, but we have a better truſt in you, for you have taine our mony.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I have ſo, truth is he was my ſervant, and for ſome chaſtiſement I gave him, he does practiſe thus upon me; ſpeake truly ſirra, are you certaine I cannot conjure?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Conjure! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but be very ſure of it.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Sure of it? why Ile make a bargaine with thee, before all theſe gentlemen, uſe all thy art, all thy roguery, and make me do any thing before al this company I have not a mind to, Ile firſt give thee leave to claime me for thy bond ſlave, and when thou haſt done hang me.

sp.speaker: Foro,
sp.p: Tis a match, ſirra, Ile make you caper ith' aire preſently.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I have too ſolid a body, and my beleife is like a Puritans on Good-Friday, too high fed with capon.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I will firſt ſend thee to Greeke land for a haunch of veniſon, juſt of the thickneſſe of thine own tallow.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Ile not ſtir an inch for thee.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Thence to Amboyna ith' Eaſt-Jndies, for pepper to bake it.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: To Amboyna? ſo I might be pepperd.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Then will I conveigh thee ſtrark naked to Develing to beg a paire of brogs, to hide thy mountainous buttocks.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: And no doublet to 'em?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: No ſir, I intend to ſend you of a ſleeveleſſe er|rand; but before you vaniſh, in regard you ſay I cannot conjure, and ar ſo ſtupid, and opinionated a ſlave, that nei|ther I, nor my art can compell you to do any thing thats beyond your own pleaſure, the gentlemen ſhall have ſome ſport; you cannot endure a cat ſirra?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Whats that to thee Iugler?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Nor you'l do nothing at my entreaty?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Ile be hang'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Sit Gentlemen, and whatſoever you ſee, be not frighted;

sp.speaker: Hosteſſ:
sp.p: Alas I can endure no coniuring.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: Stir not wife.

sp.speaker: Bian:
sp.p: Pray let me go ſir, I am not fit for theſe fooleryes.

sp.speaker: Hoſt:
sp.p: Move not daughter.

sp.speaker: For:
sp.p: I wil make you dance a new dance calld leap-frog.

sp.speaker: Clow:
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fro:
sp.p: And as naked as a frog.

sp.speaker: Clow:
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I defye thee.

div.stage: Foro. lookes in a booke, ſtrikes with his wand, Muſick playes. Enter 4. Boyes ſhap't like Frogs, and dance.

sp.speaker: Pedant:
sp.l: Spirits of the water in the likenes of frogs.
Tay: he has fiſht faire beleeve me.

sp.speaker: Mule:
sp.p: See, ſee, he ſweats and trembles.

sp.speaker: Foro:
sp.p: Are you come to your quavers?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Ile make you run diviſion on that o's ere I leave you; looke you, here are the playfellowes that are ſo in|deerd to you; come ſir, firſt uneaſe, and then dance, nay Ile make him daunce ſtark naked.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Oh let him have his ſhirt on, and his Mogols breeches, here are women ith' houſe.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Well for their ſakes he ſhall.

div.stage: Clown teares off his doublet, making ſtrange faces as if compeld to it, falls into the Daunce.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: He daunces, what a lying rogue was this to ſay the gentleman could not conjure?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: He does prettily well, but tis voluntary, I aſſure you, I have no hand in't.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: As you are a Counjurer, and a rare Artiſt, free me from theſe couplets; of all creatures I cannot endure a Frog.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: But your dauncing is voluntary, I can compell you to nothing.

sp.speaker: Hosteſ.
sp.p: O me, danghter, lets take heed of this fellow, he'le make us dance naked, an' we vex him.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Now cut capers ſirra, Ile plague that chin of yours.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, my kidneys are roſted, I drop away like a pound of butter roſted.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: He will daunce himſelfe to death.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: No matter Ile ſell his fat to the Pothecaries, and repaire my injury that way.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Enough in conſcience.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Well, at your entreaty vaniſh. And now I wil only make him breake his neck in doing a ſommerſet, and thats all the revenge I meane to take of him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: O gentlemen, what a rogue was I to belye ſo an approved Maſter in the noble datk ſcience? you can wit|neſſe, this I did only to ſpoyle his practiſe and deprive you of the happyneſſe of injoying his worthy labours; rogue that I was to do it, pray ſir forgive me.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: With what face canſt thou ask it?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: With ſuch a face as I deſerve, with a hanging looke, as all here can teſtifie.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Well gentlemen, that you may perceive the good|nes of my temper, I will entertain this rogue again in hope of amendment, for ſhould I turn him off, he would be hanged.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: You may read that in this foule coppy.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Only with this promiſe, you ſhall never cozen any of my patients.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: And remember hence forward, that though I cannot counjure, I can make you daunce ſirra, go get your ſelfe into the cottage againe. —Enter Caeſario.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I will never more daunce leape Frog: now I have got you into credit, hold it up, and cozen them in abundance.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Oh rare raſcall —Exit Clown.

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.p: How now, a Frankford mart here, a Mounte|banke, and his worſhipfull auditory.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: They are my ghueſts Sir.

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.p: A—upon them, ſhew your jugling tricks in ſome other roome.

sp.speaker: Hoſt,
sp.p: And why not here Sir?

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.p: Hence, or ſirra I ſhall ſpoile your figure fling|ing, and all their radicall queſtions.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.p: Sir we vaniſh. —Exeunt. Manet Hoſt. & Caeſar.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Signior Caeſario, you make bold with me,
And ſomewhat I muſt tell you to a degree
of ill manners, they are my ghueſts, and men I live by,
And I would know by what authority
You command thus far.

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.p: By my intereſt in your daughter.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.p: Intereſt do you call't? as J remember I never put her out to Vſury on that condition.

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.p: Pray thee be not angry.

sp.speaker: Hosteſ.
sp.l: I am come to make thee happy, and her happy:
Shee's here; alas my pretty ſoule, I am come
To give aſſurance thats beyond thy hope,
Or thy beleife, I bring repentance 'bout me,
And ſatisfaction, I will marry thee.

sp.speaker: Bianca.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: As I live I will, but do not entertain't
With too quick an apprehenſion of joy,
For that may hurt thee, I have heard ſome dye of't,

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Do not feare me.

sp.speaker: Caeſar
sp.l: Then thou think'ſt I faigne
This proteſtation, I will inſtantly
Before this teſtimony, my new alliance,
Contract my ſelfe unto thee, then I hope
We may be more private.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: But thou ſhalt not ſir,
For ſo has many a maiden-head been loſt, and many a baſtard gotten,

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: Then to give you the beſt of any aſſurance in the world,
Entreat thy father to goe fetch a Preiſt
Wee will inſtantly to bed, and there be married.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Pride hath not yet foſaken you I ſee,
Though proſperity has.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Sir you are too confident
To faſhion to your ſelfe a dreame of purchaſe
When you are a begger,

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: you are bold with me.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſ.
sp.l: Doe we not know your value is cried downe
Foureſcore i'th hundred.

sp.speaker: Bian
sp.l: Oh ſir I did love you
With ſuch a fixed heart, that in that minute
Wherein you ſlighted, or contemn'd me rather,
I tooke a vow to obey your laſt decree,
And never more looke up at any hope
Should bring me comfort that way, and though ſince
Your Foſter-mother, and the faire Clariſſa
Have in the way of marriage deſpis'd you,
That hath not any way bred my revenge,
But compaſſion rather. I have found
So much ſorrow in the way to a chaſte wedlock
That here I will ſet downe, and never wiſh
To come to'th journies end. Your ſuite to mee
Henceforth be ever ſilenc't.

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.l: My Bianca.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſ.
sp.l: Henceforward pray forbeare her and my houſe:
She's a poore vertuous wench, yet her eſtate
May weigh with yours in a gold balance.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Yes, and her birth in any Heralds office in Chriſtendome.

sp.speaker: Hoſteſ.
sp.l: It may prove ſo:
When you'l ſay, you have leapt a Whiteing. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ceſ,
sp.l: How far am I growne behind hand with fortune?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Here's Ceſario▪
My ſon ſir is to morrow to be married
Vnto the faire Clariſſa,

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Wee hope youle be a gueſte there?

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: No I will not grace your triumph ſo much.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I will not tax your breeding.
But it alters not your birth ſir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Oh ſir doe not greive him,
He has to much affliction already. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: Every way ſcorn'd and loſt,
Shame follow you
For I am growne moſt miſerable.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: Sir doe you know a Ladies ſon in towne here
They cal Ceſario?

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.l: Ther's none ſuch I aſſure thee;

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: I was told you were the man.

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.l: Whats that to thee?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: A—on't. You are melancholy, will you drink Sir?

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: With mee Sir; deſpiſe not this pitcht Canvas; the time was wee have knowne them lined with Spaniſh Duckets: I have news for you:

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.l: For me!

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: Not unleſſe you'l drink;
We are like our Sea proviſion, once out of pickle,
We require abundance of drink; I have news to tell you
That were you Prince,
Would make you ſend your mandate
To have a thouſand bonfires made 'ith City,
And piſt out agen with nothing but Greek wine.

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.l: Come, I wil drink with thee howſoever,

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.p: And upon theſe terms I wil utter my mind to you. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Alberoto, Proſpero, Juliana, and Saylors.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: SHall we bring your neceſſaries aſhore my Lord?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Do what you pleaſe, I am land-ſicke, worſe by far
Then ere I was at ſea.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Collect your ſelfe

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: O my moſt worthy Proſpero, my beſt friend,
The noble favor I receivd from thee
In freeing me from the Turks I now accompt
Worſe than my death; for I ſhall never live
To make requitall; what doe you attend for?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: To underſtand your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: They doe mock me;
I doe proteſt I have no kind of pleaſure
In any thing i'th world, butin thy friendſhip,
I muſt ever except that.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.p: Pray leave him, leave him. —Exeunt Sailors.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: The newes I heard related ſince my landing
Of the diviſion of my Family,
How is it poſſible for any man
To bear't with a ſet patience?

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: You have ſuffer'd
Since your impriſonment more waighty ſorrowes.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I, then I was a man of fleſh and bloud,
Now I am made up of fire, to the full height
Of a deadly Calenture; ô theſe vild women
That are ſo ill preſervers of mens honors,
They cannot governe their own honeſties.
That I ſhould thirty and odde winters feed
My expectation of a noble heire,
And by a womans falſhood finde him now
A fiction, a meare dreame of what he was;
And yet I love him ſtill.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: In my opinion
The ſentence (on this tryall) from the Duke
Was noble, to repaire Ceſarios loſſe
With the marriage of your wife, had you been dead.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: By your favor but it was not, I conceive
T'was diſparagment to my name, to have my widdow
Match with a Faulkners ſon, and yet beleev't
I love the youth ſtill, and much pitty him.
I doe remember at my going to Sea,
Vpon a quarrell, and a hurt receiv'd
From young Mentivole, my rage ſo farre
Oretopt my nobler temper, I gave charge
To have his hand cut off, which ſince I heard,
And to my comfort, brave Caeſario,
Worthyly prevented.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: And 'twas nobly done.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Yet the revenge, for this intent of min●
Hath bred much ſlaughter in our families,
And yet my wife (which infinitly moanes me)
Intends to marry my ſole heire Clariſſa
To the head branch of the other faction.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Tis the meane to work reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Betweene whom?

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Your ſelfe, and the worthy Baptiſta.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: O you have been of a noble and remarkable freind|ſhip,
And by this match tis generally in Florence
Hop'd, twill fully be reconcild; to me
'Twould be abſolute content.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: And to my ſelfe, I have maine intereſt in it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Noble Sir, you may command my heart to breake for you
But never to bend that way; poore Caeſario
When thou puft'ſt on thy mournfull willow garland,
Thy enemy ſhall be ſuted (I do vow)
In the ſame livery, my Caeſario
Loved as my foſter child, though not my ſonne,
Which in ſome countryes formerly were barbarous,
Was a name held moſt affectionate; thou art loſt,
Vnfortunate young man, not only ſlighted
Where thou received'ſt thy breeding, but ſince ſcorn'd
Ith' way of marriage, by the poore Bianca
The In-keepers daughter.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I have heard of that too;
But let not that afflict you; for this Lady
May happily deliver at more leaſure
A circumſtance may draw a faire event,
Better then you can hope for.
For this preſent we muſt leave you,
And ſhall viſit you againe within theſe two houres.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Ever to me moſt welcome,—O my Caeſario.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: I am none of yours Sir, ſo tis proteſted;
And I humbly beg,
Since tis not in your power to preſerve me
Any longer in a noble courſe of life,
Give me a worthy death.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: The youth is mad.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Nay Sir, I will inſtruct you in a way
To kill me honorably.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: That were moſt ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: I am turning Pirate, You may be imployed
By the Duke to fetch me in; and in a ſea-fight
Give me a noble grave.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Queſtionleſſe he's mad; I would give any Doctor
A thouſand crownes to free him from this ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: Here's the Phyſitian. —Shewes a Poniard

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Hold Sir, I did ſay
To free you from the ſorrow, not from life.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Why life and ſorrow are unſeparable.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Be comforted Caeſario, Mentivole
Shall not marry Clariſſa.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: No Sir, ere he ſhall, Ile kill him.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: But you forfeit your own life then.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: Thats worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Caeſario, be thy ſelfe, be mine Caeſario,
Make not thy ſelfe uncapable of that portion
I have full purpoſe to confer upon thee;
By falling into madneſſe, beare thy wrongs
With noble patience, the afflicted freind
Which ever in all actions crownes the end.

sp.speaker: Ceſ.
sp.l: You well awake me▪ nay recover'd me
Both to ſence and full life, ô moſt noble ſir,
Though I have loſt my fortune, and loſt you
For a worthy Father: yet I will not looſe
My former vertue, my integrity
Shall not yet forſake me; but as the wilde Ivy,
Spredds and thrives better in ſome pittious ruin
Of tower, or defac'd Temple, then it does
Planted by a new building- ſo ſhall I
Make my adverſity my inſtrument
To winde me up into a full content.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Tis worthily reſolv'd; our firſt adventure
Is to ſtop the marriage; for thy other loſſes,
Practis'd by a womans malice, but account them
Like conjurers windes rais'd to a fearefull blaſt,
And doe ſome miſcheife, but do never laſt. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Now ſir, will you not acknowledge that I have mightily advancte your practice?

sp.speaker: Foroboſ.
sp.p: Tis confeſt, and I will make thee a great man for't.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I take a courſe to do that my ſelfe, for I drinke ſack in abundance.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: O my rare raſcall. We muſt remove.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Any whither: Europe is to little to be cozned by us, I am ambitious to goe to the Eaſt-Indies, thou and I to ride on our brace of Elephants.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: And for my part I long to be in England agen; you wil never get ſo much as in England, we have ſhifted many countryes, and many names: but traunce the world over you ſhall never purſe up ſo much gold as when you were in England, and call'd your ſelfe Doctor Lambe|ſtones.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Twas an atractive name I confeſſe, women were then my only admirers.

sp.speaker: Clow,
sp.p: And all their viſits was either to further their luſt, or reveng injuries.

sp.speaker: Foro
sp.p: You ſhould have forty in a morning beleager my cloſett, and ſtrive who ſhould be cozend firſt, a|mongſt foureſcore love-ſick waighting women that has come to me in a morning to learne what fortune ſhould betide them in their firſt marriage, I have found above 94 to have loſt their maidenheads.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: By their owne confeſſion, but I was faine to be your male midwife, and worke it out of them by cir|cumſtance.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Thou waſt, and yet for all this frequent reſort of women and thy handling of their urinalls and their caſes, thou art not given to lechery, what ſhould be the reaſon of it? thou haſt wholſome fleſh enough about thee; me thinkes the divell ſhould tempt thee too't.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: What need he do that, when he makes me his inſtrument to tempt others.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Thou canſt not chuſe but utter thy rare good parts; thou waſt an excellent baude I acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Well, and what I have done that way I will ſpare to ſpeake of all you and I have done ſir, and though we ſhould—

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: We will for England, thats for certaine.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: We ſhall never want there.

sp.speaker: Foro,
sp.p: Want? the Court of Wards ſhall want mony firſt, for I profeſſe my ſelfe Lord Paramount over fooles and madfolkes.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Do but ſtore your ſelfe with lyes enough againſt you come thither,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: VVhy thats all the familarity I ever had with the Divell, my guift of lying, they ſay hees the Father of lyes, and though I cannot conjure, yet I profeſſe my ſelfe to be one of his poore goſſips. I will now reveale to thee a rare peece of ſervice.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: VVhat is it my moſt worſhipful Doctor Lamb|ſtones.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: There is a Captaine come lately from Sea,
They call Proſper I ſaw him this morning
Through a chincke of wainſcote that divides my lodging
sp.p: And the Hoſt of the houſe, withdraw my Hoſt, and Hoſteſſe, the faire Biancha, and an antient gentlewoman into their bedchamber; I could not overheare their con|ference, but I ſaw ſuch a maſſe of gold & Iewels, & when he had done he loc't it up into a casket; great joy there was amongſt them & forth they are gone into the city, and my Hoſt told me at his going forth he thought he ſhould not returne till after ſupper; now ſir, in their ab|ſence will we fall to our picklocks, enter the chamber, ſeize the Iewels, make an eſcape from Florence, and wee are made for ever.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: But if they ſhould goe to a true conjurer, and fetch us back in a whirle winde?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Doe not beleeve there is any ſuch fetch in Aſtro|logy, and this may be a meanes to make us live honeſt hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Tis but an ill road too't that lyes through the high way of theeving.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: For indeed I am weary of this trade of fortune-telling, and meane to give all over, when I come into England, for it is a very tickliſh quality.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: And ith end will hang by a twine thred.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Beſides the Iſland has too many of the profeſſion, they hinder one anothers market.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: No, no, the pillory hinders their market.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: You know there the jugling captaine.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: I theres a ſure carde.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Onely the fore-man of their jury is dead, but he dyed like a Roman.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Elſe tis thought he had made worke for the hangman.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: And the very Ball of your falſe prophets, hee's quaſht too.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: He did meaſure the ſtarres with a falſe yard, and may now travaile to Rome with a morter on's head to ſee if he can recover his mony that way.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Come, come, lets fiſh for this casket, and to Sea preſently.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: We ſhall never reach London I feare;
My minde runs ſo much of hanging landing at wapping.
This well may be a day of joy long wiſh'd for
To my Clariſſa, ſhee is innocent.
Nor can her youth but with an open boſome
Meet Himens pleaſing bounties, but to me
That am invirond with black guilt and horror
It does appeare a funerall though promiſing much
Jn the conception were hard to mannage
But ſad in the event, it was not hate
But fond indulgence in me to preſerve
Ceſarios threatned life in open court
That forc'd me to diſclaime him, chooſing rather
To rob him of his birth-right, and honor
Then ſuffer him to run the hazard of
Inrag'de Baptistas fury, while he lives;
I know I have a ſonne, and the Dukes ſentence
A while deluded, and this tempeſt over,
When he aſſures himſelfe deſpaire hath ſeizd him.
I can relieve and raiſe him—ſpeake, who is it
That preſſes on my privacies? Sir your pardon.
You cannot come unwelcome, though it were
To reade my ſecret thoughts.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Lady to you
Mine ſhall be ever open; Lady ſaid I,
That name keeps too much diſtance, ſiſter rather
I ſhould have ſtilde you, and I now may claime it,
Since our divided families are made one
By this bleſſed marriage; to whoſe honor comes
The Duke in perſon, waited on by all
The braveries of his Coutt, to witneſſe it,
And then to be our gheſts, is the bride ready
To meet and entertaine him?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: She attends the comming of your ſonne.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Pray you bring her forth.
The Dukes at hand—Muſick in her loud voyce,
Speakes his arrivall.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Shee's prepard to meet it. —Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mariana, Clariſſa led by two Maides: at the other doore, Baptiſta meetes with Mentivole, led by two Courtiers, the Duke, Biſhop; diverſe Attendants: (A Song) whilſt they ſalute.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It were impertinent to wiſh you joy,
Since all joyes dwell about you, Himens torch
Was never ſlighted with a luckier omen,
Nor burnt with ſo much ſplendor, to defer
With fruitleſſe complement, the meanes to make
Your certain pleaſures lawfull to the world;
Since in the union of your hearts they are
Confirmd already: would but argue us
A boaſter of our favours; to the Temple
And there the ſacred knot once tyde, all t'riumphs
Our Dukedome can affoord, ſhall grace your nuptialls.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: On there.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I hope it is not in the power
Of any to croſſe us now.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: But in the breath
Of a wrongd Father I forbid the bands.

sp.speaker: Ceſar.
sp.l: What, doe you ſtand at gaze?

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Riſen from the dead!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Although the ſea had vomitted up the figure
In which thy better part livd long impriſond,
True love deſpiſing feare, runs thus to meete it.

sp.speaker: Clariſ.
sp.l: In duty I kneele to it.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Hence vile wretches,
To you I am a ſubſtance incorporeall,
And not to be prophand, with your vile touch?
That could ſo ſoone forget me, but ſuch things
Are neither worth my anger, nor reproofe.
To you great ſir, I turne my ſelfe and theſe
Immediate Miniſters of your government,
And if in my rude language I tranſgreſſe;
Aſcribe it to the cold remembrance of
My ſervices, and not my rugged temper.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Speake freely, be thy language ne're ſo bitter,
To ſee thee ſafe Alberto, ſignes thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: My pardon? I can need none, it it be not
Receivd for an offence. I tamely beare
Wrongs, which a ſlave-born Muſcovite would check at.
Why if for treaſon I had beene deliverd
Vp to the hangmans Axe, and this dead trunck
Vnworthy of a Chriſtian Sepulcher;
Expoſd a prey to feed the ravenous vulture,
The memory of the much I oft did for you,
Had you but any touch of gratitude,
Or thought of my deſervings, would have ſtopd you
From theſe unjuſt proceedings.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Heare the motives that did induce us.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I have heard them all,
Your highneſſe ſentence, the whole Court abuſd,
By the perjuries, and practiſe of this woman.
(Wee peſt thou Crocodile) my hopefull ſon,
Whom I dare ſweare mine owne, degraded of
The honors that deſcend to him from me:
And from that in his love ſcornd by a creature
Whoſe baſe birth though made eminent by her beauty,
Might well have markd her out Ceſarios ſervant,
All this I could have pardond and forgot;
But that my daughter with my whole eſtate
So hardly purchaſd, is aſſignd a dower;
To one whoſe Father, and whoſe family
I ſo de●eſt; that I would looſe my eſſence
And be transformed to a Baſiliske
To look them dead, to mee's an injury,
Admits no ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Ther's none offerd.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Nor would not be accepted,
Though upon thy knees twere tenderd.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Now the ſtorme grows high.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: But that I thought thee dead, and in thy death
The brinie Ocean had entombd thy name;
I would have ſought a wife in a Bordello
For my Mentivole, and gladly hugd
Her ſpurious Iſſue as my lawfull Nephewes,
Before his blood ſhould ere have mixd with thine;
So much I ſcorne it.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I'll not bandy words, but thus diſſolve the contract.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: There I meet thee, and ſeize on whats mine owne.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: For all my ſervice,
Great Sir grant me the combat with this wretch,
That I may ſcourge his inſolence.

sp.speaker: Baptist.
sp.l: I kneele for it.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.l: And to approve my ſelfe Albertos ſonne,
Ile be his ſecond upon any odds,
Gainſt him that dare moſt of Baptiſtas race.

sp.speaker: Menti.
sp.l: Already upon honorable termes,
In me thou haſt met thy better, for her ſake
I'le adde no more.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: Sir, let our ſwords decide it.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: O ſtay Sir, and as you would hold the title
Of a juſt Prince, ere you grant licence to
Theſe mad-mens fury, lend your private eare
To the moſt diſtres'd of women.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Speake, tis granted. He takes Mariana aſide.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In the meane time, let not Clariſſa be
A patient looker on, though as yet doubtfull,
To whom to bend her knee firſt, yet to all
I ſtoop thus low in duty, and would waſh
The duſt of fury with my Virgin teares,
From his bleſſd feete, and make them beautifull
That would move to conditions of peace,
Though with a ſnaile like pace, they all are wingd
To beare you to deſtruction: reverend ſirs,
Think on your ancient friendſhip caemented
With ſo much bloud, but ſhed in noble action,
Divided now in paſſion for a brawle;
The makers bluſh to own, much lov'd Caeſario.
Brother, or friend, (each title may prevaile,)
Remember with what tenderneſſe from our child-hood
Wee lov'd together, you preferring me
Before your ſelfe, and I ſo fond of you
That it begot ſuſpition in ill mindes
That our affection was inceſtuous.
Thinke of that happy time, in which I know
That with your deereſt blood you had prevented
This ſhowre of teares from me Mentivole,
My husband, regiſtred in that bright ſtar-chamber,
Though now on earth made ſtrangers, be the example
And offer in one hande the peacefull Olive
Of concord▪ or if that can be denyed
By powerfull interceſſion in the other
Carry the Hermian rod and force atonement,
Now we will not bee all marble. Deaths the worſt then
And hee ſhall be my bridegroome, offers to kill her ſelfe

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Hold Clariſſa, his loving violence needs muſt
Offer inſpite of honor —he ſnatches away her knife and ſets it to his owne breast, ſhe ſtayes his hand.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Was it to that end then on your religion?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And my hope in heaven Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Wee then will leave entreaties, and make uſe
Of our authority, muſt I cry ai-me
To this unheard of inſolence? in my preſence
To draw your ſwords, and as all reverence
Thats due to majeſty were forfeited,
cheriſh this wilderneſſe! ſheath them inſtantly,
and ſhew an alteration in your lookes, or by my power

sp.speaker: Alber,
sp.l: Cut of my head

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: And mine, rather then heare of peace with this bad man.
I'le not alone give up my throat, but ſuffer
Your rage to reach my family.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And my name to be no more remembred.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are theſe?

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.p: Biancha, tis Biancha, ſtill Biancha: but ſtrangely alter'd.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: If that thirteene yeares
Of abſence could raze from my memory
The figure of my freind, I might forget thee;
But if thy Image be graven on my heart,
Thou art my Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Thou my Baptiſta?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A ſuddaine change!

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: I dare not aske deere freind
If Juliana live! for thats a bleſſing
I am unworthy of, but yet deny not
To let me know the place ſhe hath made happy
By having there her ſepulcher.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: If your highneſſe pleaſe to vouchſafe a patient
Eare wee ſhall make a true relation of a ſtory
That ſhall call on your wonder.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Speake, wee heare you.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Baptiſtas Fortune in the Genoa court,
His baniſhment, with his faire wifes reſtraint
You are acquainted with; what ſince hath follow'd
I faithfully will deliver, ere eight moones
After Baptiſtas abſence were compleate,
Faire Juliana founde the pleaſures that
They had injoy'd together were not barren,
And bluſhing at the burthen of her wombe,
No father neere to owne it, it drew on
A violent ſickneſſe, which call'd downe compaſſion
From the angry Duke, then carefull of her health.
Phyſitians were enquir'd of, and their judgment
Preſcrib'd the Bathes of Luca as a meanes
For her recovery; to my charge it pleas'd her
To be committed; but as on the way
Wee journy'd, thoſe throwes only knowne to women
Came thick upon her, in a private village.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Shee died?

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Have patience, ſhe brought to the world
A hopefull daughter; for her bodies ſickneſſe
It ſoone decai'd, but the greife of her minde
Hourely increas'd, and life grew tedious to her,
And deſperate ere to ſee you; ſhe injoyn'd me
To place her in a Greeekiſh Monaſtery,
And to my care gave up her pretty daughter.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: What monaſtery? as a Pilgrim bare-foot,
Ile ſearch it out.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Pray you interrupt me not,
Now to my fortunes; the girle well dispos'd off
With a faithfull freind of mine, my cruell fate
Made me a priſoner to the Turkiſh gallies,
Where for 12 yeares, theſe hands tugd at the oare,
But fortune tyr'd at length with my afflictions,
Some ſhips of Malta mett the Ottaman fleete,
Charg'd them and boorded them, and gave me freedome
With my deliverers I ſerv'd, and gott
Such reputation with the great Maſter
That he gave me command over a tall
And luſty ſhip, where my firſt happy ſervice
Was to redeeme Alberto rumor'd dead,
But was like me ſurpris'd by Cortugogly.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: I would I had dyed there.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: And from him learning
Baptiſta liv'd, and their diſſolved freindſhip,
I hois'd up ſailes for Greece, found Iuliana
A votary at her beades; having made knowne
Both that you liv'd, and where you were, ſhe borrow'd
So much from her devotion as to wiſh me
To bring her to you; if the object pleaſe you,
With joy receave her.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Rage and fury leave me- throwes away his ſword
I am ſo full of happines, theres no room left
To entertaine you, O my long loſt Iewell,
Light of mine eyes, my ſoules ſtrength.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: My beſt Lord, having Embrac'd you thus,
Death cannot fright me.

sp.speaker: Bapt.
sp.l: Live long to do ſo though J ſhould fix here.
Pardon me Proſpero though I enquire my daughters for|tune.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: That your happineſſe
May be at all parts perfect, here ſhe is!

sp.speaker: Caeſ.
sp.l: Biancha daughter to a princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: True with my faithfull Hoſt I left her,
And with him till now ſhe hath reſided,
Ignorant both of her birth and greatneſſe.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: O my bleſt one. Ioy upon joy over-whelmes me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Above wonder.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I doe begin to melt too, this ſtrange ſtory
Workes much upon me.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Since it hath ples'd heaven
To grace us with this miracle, I that am
Heavens inſtrument here, determine thus; Alberto
Be not unthankefull for the bleſſings ſhowne you,
Nor you Baptiſta; diſcord was yet never
A welcome ſacrifice; therefore rage layd by,
Embrace as freinds, and let paſs'd difference
Be as a dreame forgotten.

sp.speaker: Bap.
sp.l: Tis to me.

sp.speaker: Alber.
sp.l: And me, and thus confirme it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And to tye it
In bonds not to be broken, with the marriage▪
Of young Mentivole, and faire Clariſſa,
So you conſent great Lady, your Biancha
Shall call Caeſario Husband.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Tis a motion I gladly yeeld too.

sp.speaker: Caeſar.
sp.p: One in which you make a ſadd man hap|py. Offers to kneele.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Kneele not, all forgiven.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: With the Duke your Vnkle I will make attone|ment, and will have no denyall.

div.stage: Enter Hoſt, Foroboſco, Clowne and Officers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let this day be ſtill held ſacred.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Now if you can conjure, let the Divell unbind you,

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Wee are both undone,

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Already wee feele it.

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: Iuſtice ſir,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are they?

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I can reſolve you, ſlaves freed from the Gallyes
By the Viceroy of Sicilia.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Whats their offence?

sp.speaker: Hoſt.
sp.l: The robbing me of all my plate and Iewels,
I meane the attempting of it,

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Pleaſe your grace I will now diſcover this var|let in earneſt, this honeſt peſtilent rogue, profeſt the art on conjuring, but all the skill that ever he had in the black art was in making a ſeacole fire; only with wearing ſtrange ſhapes he begot admiration amongſt fooles and women.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Wilt thou preach thou varlet?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why does he gogle with his eyes, and ſtauke ſo?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: This is one of his Magicall raptures.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I doe vilifie your cenſure, you demand if I am guilty, whir ſayes my cloake by a tricke fo legerdemaine, now I am not guilty, I am guarded with innocence, pure ſilver lace I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Thus have I read to you your vertues, which notwithſtanding I would not have you proud of.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: Out thou concealement of tallow, and counter|feit Mummia.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: To the Gallyes with them both.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: The onely ſea phyſick for a knave ia to be baſted in a gally with the oyle of a Bulls peeſell.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: And will not you make a ſoure face at the ſame ſauce, ſirra? I hope to finde thee ſo leane, in one fortnight thou mayeſt be drawne by the eares through the hoop of a firkin.

sp.speaker: Duke,
sp.p: Divide them and away with them to'th Gallyes.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: This will take downe your pride Iugler.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This day that hath given birth to bleſſings; be|yond hope, admits no criminall ſentence, to the Temple and there with humbleneſſe praiſe heavens bounties;
sp.l: For bleſſings nere diſcend from thence, but when
A ſacrifice in thankes aſcends from men. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: THE PROLOGVE.
div.l: Playes have their fates, not as in their true ſence
They're underſtood, but as the influence
Of idle custome madly workes upon
The droſſe of many tongu'd opinion.
A worthy story, how ſoever writ
For language, modeſt mirth, conceite or witt,
Meetes often times with the ſweett commendation
Of hang't, tis ſcurvy, when for approbation
A Iigg ſhall be clapt at, and every rime
Prais'd and applauded by a clamorous chime.
Let Jgnorance and laughter dwell together,
They are beneath the Muſes pitty. Hether
Come nobler Iudgements, and to thoſe the ſtraine
Of our invention is not bent in vaine.
The faire Maide of the Jnne to you commends
Her hopes and welcomes, and withall intends
In th' Entertaines to which ſhe doth invite ye,
All things to pleaſe, and ſome things to delight yee.
